messages.text:
Hi there! I am very proud to announce the first beta release of LocalSearchSolvers.jl, a framework for CBLS (Constraint-Based Local Search) solvers in pure Julia, hosted on the GitHub org JuliaConstraints.
Its goal is to solve satisfaction and optimization problems where models are formulated as a simple triplet of variables domains, constraints, and optional objectives.
Due to high scalability, CBLS can have more than linear speedup with parallelization (though not yet implemented here), and many other options are coming such as dynamic models, DSL for JuMP and Minizinc, automatic parameter tuning and such.

elements.text:

Its goal is to solve satisfaction and optimization problems where models are formulated as a simple triplet of variables domains, constraints, and optional objectives.
Due to high scalability, CBLS can have more than linear speedup with parallelization (though not yet implemented here), and many other options are coming such as dynamic models, DSL for JuMP and Minizinc, automatic parameter tuning and such.

messages.text: made a thing: <https://github.com/jakobnissen/ScanByte.jl> . It's a package for scanning a piece of memory for the first occurence of a byte from a set of bytes. I made it very, very fast, like ridiculous fast, so it can be used for things like a Regex implementation or a text search engine or whatever. I'm using it for making parsers myself.

messages.text:
Announcing `LibDeflate` v 0.2.
LibDeflate is a package for working with gzip and/or DEFLATE-zipped data. Version 0.2 brings gzip functionality (previous it was just DEFLATE). There are two reasons to use the package:
• It's about 4x faster than `CodecZlib` and with slightly better compression ratios.
• It gives access to the internal fields of gzip data. For example, did you know there can be comments, filenames and extra fields in gzip files? LibDeflate extracts them all.
However, it does not support streaming, so all data processing must happen entirely in RAM.

v 0.2.
LibDeflate is a package for working with gzip and/or DEFLATE-zipped data. Version 0.2 brings gzip functionality (previous it was just DEFLATE). There are two reasons to use the package:
and with slightly better compression ratios.
It gives access to the internal fields of gzip data. For example, did you know there can be comments, filenames and extra fields in gzip files? LibDeflate extracts them all.
However, it does not support streaming, so all data processing must happen entirely in RAM.
